history.content:
Take upper div classes to boost and meet GPA. Or switch to CogSci.

For students who started at Berkeley Fall 2015 or after, if students do not reach the 3.30 GPA, they will not be able to declare the CS major, unfortunately. Because of this, we highly recommend planning for backup majors. No other courses will count towards the 3.30 GPA calculations besides CS 61A, 61B, and 70, so upper divsion courses will NOT count.
Take upper div classes to boost and meet GPA. Or switch to CogSci.

If students do not reach the 3.30 GPA, they will not be able to declare the CS major, unfortunately. Because of this, we highly recommend planning for backup majors. No other courses will count towards the 3.30 GPA calculations besides CS 61A, 61B, and 70, so upper divsion courses will count.

children.subject: Similar, but with EECS there's definitely a much larger technical requirement and (in my opinion) a much less holistic education. L&S Breadths are actually pretty cool. EE classes (again, IMO)... not so much.

Not that the situation doesn't suck, but if you look at the grade distributions reported on https://schedulebuilder.berkeley.edu/, you'll see that the typical average is a B for 61A, B+/B for 61B, and B for 70. I wouldn't call a B+ "well, well, well above average" for any of those.

Ironically, some lower div CS classes have been inflating grades just a bit because the instructors sympathize with the GPA cutoffs that students face. For example, lower divs are departmentally mandated to have a 2.70-2.90 average GPA. 

It's also worth noting that these grades don't take into account people who drop after the first midterm because it was too hard for them or people who P/NP after the second because they're working at a slightly slower pace than the class is going and are having trouble keeping up. These scores which aren't counted also tend to skew much lower than the average (and if they were, would likely bring the average down enough that "well, well, well above average" wouldn't be an exaggeration).

^what is your point then about the instructors who "sympathize with the GPA cutoffs"? if we're supposed to have a B-/B average but are actually getting a B/B+ average, i don't see how you're using that to support your original argument criticizing berkeley's cs program guidelines.

also, there is historically a very significant fraction of the people who P/NP the 3 courses who aren't going into the major, (especially 61a). considering this, the total fraction of people who come into berkeley to study CS who end up P/NP'ing these classes is pretty small (proportion of people taking it for letter grade is easily greater than 90%).

considering all this, saying a B+ in the 3 classes is "well, well, well above average" is a ridiculous statement. and even if you consider it so "well, well, well above average", i still don't see why you couldn't have applied to eecs and taken the classes you want anyway (the eecs core curriculum can easily be completed in 3 years, you have enough time to take the "holistic" classes you want)

EECS is tougher to double major with, especially if you are interested in non-technical classes or in Math/Stats/Linguistics/Econ/Business. It's not a question of can you do the EECS requirements (CS and EECS could probably do each other's requirements just fine). It is do you want to take those classes. 

EECS does have the benefit of being admitted into the major. I really really wish they did the same for CS.

Freakin Berkeley man... L&S CS should just be an impacted major you apply into directly from High School (with the ability to also apply if you get a 3.3 in prereqs for the peeps who don't know they wanna be CS from the start). Its ridiculous that people who come to Berkeley FOR cs can't be IN cs if they don't get a well, well, well above average GPA in 3 classes.
No, if you bothered to look at the question and answer, you must get 3.3 or above to declare CS.

Are there any sort of exceptions to the students who don't make the 3.3 GPA. For example if a student received a 3.2, and wrote a convincing statement about their passion for CS, could they still be considered?

history.content: What do students do if they don't make the 3.3 for the CS declaration? What if they are close?
history.subject: 3.3 Declaration
